repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
# include "decoration.h.inline.generated.h"
#endif

inline int decor_redraw_col(win_T *wp, int col, int win_col, bool hidden, DecorState *state)
  FUNC_ATTR_ALWAYS_INLINE
```
I made the function `static inline` because otherwise "decoration.h.inline.generated.h" is empty and linking fails with unresolved symbol error.

Looks like 4+ new fields were added, and a lot of related logic. Is there any way to extract parts of the logic to common functions, to help with understanding it in the future? Or some other way to simplify the code?

comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -247,7 +247,7 @@ OPTIONS
 
 PERFORMANCE
 
-• TODO
+• Significantly reduced redraw time for long lines with syntax highlighting.

comment_data.body: We don't use bitfields in our owned code, better to change the typedef to `typedef uint8_t DecorRangeKind`
Are ephemeral decorations primarily used by treesitter?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -247,7 +247,7 @@ OPTIONS
 
 PERFORMANCE
 
-• TODO
+• Significantly reduced redraw time for long lines with syntax highlighting.

comment_data.body: We are pretty consistent in our docs in distinguishing (legacy) "syntax highlighting" from "treesitter highlighting". So this is more about consistent user documentation than technical correctness.

comment_regular_data.body:
`draw_virt_text()` and `handle_inline_virtual_text()` now iterate only through active ranges. They don't check the range position to know if it's active, but they check for `draw_col` being a value other than -10, and it seems that all inactive ranges have `draw_col` == -10 and it is set to a different value only when the range becomes active:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/4833a63929a83c11379036ead33913711134015b/src/nvim/decoration.c#L661-L664

The `test / ubuntu asan clang oldtest (pull_request)` failed likely because I took address of the first element of an empty array:
```c
#define kv_A(v, i) ((v).items[(i)])
...
DecorRangeSlot *const slots = &kv_A(state->slots, 0);
```

Can I directly access the `items` of the `kvect_t` structs?

> The `test / ubuntu asan clang oldtest (pull_request)` failed likely because I took address of the first element of an empty array:
> 
> ```c
> #define kv_A(v, i) ((v).items[(i)])
> ...
> DecorRangeSlot *const slots = &kv_A(state->slots, 0);
> ```
> 
> Can I directly access the `items` of the `kvect_t` structs?

`items` of empty `kvec_t` is `NULL`

> > The `test / ubuntu asan clang oldtest (pull_request)` failed likely because I took address of the first element of an empty array:
> > ```c
> > #define kv_A(v, i) ((v).items[(i)])
> > ...
> > DecorRangeSlot *const slots = &kv_A(state->slots, 0);
> > ```
> > 
> > 
> >     
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >       
> >     
> > 
> >     
> >   
> > Can I directly access the `items` of the `kvect_t` structs?
> 
> `items` of empty `kvec_t` is `NULL`

Yes, but it reads nothing from the array if it is empty. 

I use the pointer to elements instead of accessing the elements through `kv_A()` all the time but getting the pointer through `&kv_A(state->slots, 0)` triggers asan.
Yes, but ASAN doesn't allow you to use `[0]` on a NULL pointer. You can assign `->items` to the pointer directly instead.

If you have benchmark code available, you may want to add it somewhere in `test/benchmark/`.

Please add a sentence in `:help news-features`, there is currently a lonely "Performance" section there :) Something like `Reduced redraw time by 400x when ...` is something users love to see.

I added the benchmarks and news.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/eaf7ffc3-3fae-4c71-9032-882fd25fc314)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/91d214f3-a312-4d41-b57b-1e9856bcb48a)

Benchmarks stress-test the code (decor ranges intersect and are out of order).

I noticed that the original behavior was not always consistent. Normal extmarks can be added both before and after ephemeral extmarks. For example, with this lua highlights file: 
```
(function_declaration) @testing1
```

and this test file:
```lua
----
function ignore() end
function test()
local a = 5
  if a > 10 then
    print('something')
    a = a + 10
  end
end

vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, '@testing1', { fg = 'green' })
vim.api.nvim_set_hl(0, 'testing2', { fg = 'blue', italic = true })
local ns = vim.api.nvim_create_namespace('testing')
vim.api.nvim_buf_clear_namespace(0, ns, 0, -1)
vim.api.nvim_buf_set_extmark(0, ns, 0, 0, {
  end_row = 5,
  end_col = 1,
  priority = 100,
  hl_group = 'testing2',
})
```

After sourcing the file, it looks like this (notice that the first and second function are displayed with different highlights where the regular and ephemeral extmarks intersect):
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d0f3da58-4057-40a3-ad3f-7aaf2d2a030c)
But after updating line 3 (for example by jumping with `cursorline`), it changes the highlight:
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/216d4198-2ebd-44e9-978c-b4fabb6b9f62)

And it can be reverted back by updating the first line at the same time (for example with `:redraw!` or visual selection):
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/bfb45ee5-6845-48ad-aa34-66b30c721a1e)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/8a8c6134-9aa0-40d0-a1c5-d0c7bc6382a1)

This PR doesn't change this behavior.
Rebased and added a comment that info about freed `DecorRange`s is stored in a freelist

The decor provider concept is going to need to be re-engineered to support long lines "natively". The rationale for the current `on_line` entry point and the quite naive `kvec_t(DecorRange)` is that there is a limited amount of work and resulting marks per line, which of course flies out of the window if the rest of the editor is refactored to allow really really long lines without exploding (think opening a 10MB log.json file without linebreaks directly). The new API for 0.12 is going to need to replace it with `on_range` for arbitrary ranges of text (which both can be multi-line when we have trivially short lines, and multi-callback per line for looong lines) to be prepared for this possible future.

The other end of the design spectrum would be to replace `kvec_t(DecorState)` with a separate `MarkTree(extmark)` for ephemeral decoration. I don't think that should be done just yet, but that would be the natural end point of making DecorState "smarter" as a solution, if we end up concluding that will be necessary despite these planned API improvements.   

That being said, if this micro-optimization does make end-user experience noticeably better already, we _should_ merge this PR for 0.11 pretty much as is. The fact it contains a benchmark is a huge plus and something which will remain even if the implementation is changed later.
Meanwhile another rebase will help here, and keeping it rebased will increase confidence.

Rebased.

I couldn't find anything that I could factor out since only thing that is repeated multiple times in iteration bounds.
It's not obvious to me what a lot of the new blocks are doing without studying them thoroughly. Could you at least add some comments on what's going on and the rationale for it.

title: perf(decor): improve performance for long lines
